WRITING.TEXT: Took my daughter (3 at the time) and younger brother camping on an island in the middle of the lake one summer afternoon. We would yell random words to hear the distinct 3 echos that would come back at different times. For some reason my daughter yelled "PENIS" out of the blue. My brother and I both started cracking up and we started yelling it too. For the next 2 months my daughter would randomly yell penis as loud as she could to see if there was an echo. I couldn't be mad at her, but her mother on the other hand ......

Friend And I decided to go offroading in my Suzuki samurai one night due to boredom. There was a big thunderstorm that had just passed and everything was drenched. We are driving up the mountain to this local offroad spot, imagine a 5 mile twisty gravel road. There is one spot where the trees clear and you can see everything around you for miles. As we approach this spot there appears to be a thick white cloud or fog bank, but its small, about 50 foot in diameter. I slow down as it is so thick we cannot see through it. The INSTANT we drive into it everything electrical dies. Headlights, gauges, engine, radio etc. We both look at each other as I attempt to re start the samurai but nothing. At this point it seems like maybe a battery cable came loose so I get my phone out to use the flashlight. What do you know its off too. My friend checks his phone too and its the same way, dead and wont power up. We are starting to get a little freaked out. Unsure what we should do we just sit there. About a minute passes and suddenly the "fog" slowly moves to the left. We couldnt tell this at the time because we are still inside of it blind. The instant the fog cleared us everything electrical came back to life. The headlights come on, radio starts playing and our phones start powering up. I reach forward and turn the key and it fires up no problem. I back up and see whatever it was we drove into floating off to the left at about walking speed. Still dont know what it is to this day but it was pretty strange and incredible timing to be a coincidence.
Kermit did a simulated Strafing run on us in this p-51 last time I was at Fantasy of Flight. What an awesome place, it a shame he closed it to the public.

WRITING.TITLE: started my battlecar
WRITING.TEXT: Got bored with my track car miata, took it in the woods and loved it. Im building a 4 link with a toyota 4runner solid rear axle and some long travel front control arms. Should be fun. Im shooting for 12" of travel. Hopefully the picture works. https://reddit-uploaded-media.s3-accelerate.amazonaws.com/images%2Ft2_ep4xolh%2Fb5utx1dzkqb01
MAYBE https://youtu.be/VT8Nf8h9QQ0

I overdo everything. The toyota solid rear axle will be locked, either welded or itll have a spool. I build suspension for a living so it comes naturally for me. This will essentially get a scaled down trophy truck setup. 29" tall mud tires.

built some quick bolt in extended shock towers to test the fox air shocks and see if they will work appropriately. [IMG]http://i66.tinypic.com/w7lb8w.jpg[/IMG] [IMG]http://i65.tinypic.com/2hzs6jr.jpg[/IMG]

I met a guy working pit out at Road atlanta waiting on my session to go out. He told me he has a grand national v6 swapped miata. Opposite of what OP asked but still really cool. He told me his friend was just finishing putting a Jag v12 in his miata.
I run 1:33s in my 350hp civic

One day I was at a friends house and happened to be grilling hamburgers. My friend did something annoying and my response was to lightly jab him in the throat with the spatula. Little did i realize the end of the spatula has hot as hell since I had been keeping it on the grill. He got a pretty severe burn right across the front of his throat, there was no hiding it. He said he lost track of the amount of people that asked him why he tried to kill himself by cutting his own throat. About 10 years later I think the scar has faded. Same guy also got his shirt burnt off of him by a bottle rocket as he was jumping on the trampoline. I had a 1/1000000 shot hit him square in the chest as he was jumping. luckily that one didnt hurt him.

I love my xb9r. My dad bought it brand new in 2003 and I got it 4 years ago when he got too fat to ride it. I took it apart 3 years ago for no reason and havent put it back together yet. One day I will. I bought an fz09 yesterday to ride and enjoy.

WRITING.TITLE: 100% impulse buy, totally satisfied.
WRITING.TEXT: https://imgur.com/gallery/wWoIv4K A little back story. In 2014 I ordered a liquid metallic fz09 when they first came out. The dealer calls me about a month later and says, "your bike is here, you can come pick it up". I arrive at the dealership where they have a RED bike for me. I politely say I ordered the grey one with blue wheels and I dont want a red one. They basically tell me too bad you cant choose the color and I proceed to walk out. I never got one. Fast forward 4 years and the itch came back. See I have about 10 other motorcycles but they are constantly taken apart in various stages of customization. I wanted something to ride now. I hadnt thrown a leg over something in 2 years. Thursday I find a nicely modded fz09 in the color I like with low miles, then I make it mine. In the last 3 days ive put 400 miles on it just playing around town. Its everything I had hoped it was and im totally in love with it.
correct, neutral coasting with glove off to take the picture.
its already got a penskie twin clicker, and ill definitely do something to the forks.
i love the gauge. Its got way more features than im used to.

WRITING.TITLE: The natural progression of my Na6.

WRITING.TEXT: Click the link for pics. The car has previous crash damage, lots of rust and I blew the engine up at its 6th track day.
NA is a first generation car, a 1990. The 6 means its a 1.6 liter engine. Later NA cars were 1.8 liter engines and a few other changes, they were NA8's.

WRITING.TITLE: Make a quick exhaust from scraps this morning. Sounds great.

WRITING.TEXT: I plan on making it black later to help it blend in. Its 10 lbs lighter than the stock setup and much less restrictive so it cant hurt. It pulls slightly harder but I think I need to adjust the tune to see any real benefit. I have noticed some popping at wot in 1-3 gear, almost sounds like traction control cutting in.
Awesome. What brand endmills are these?

WRITING.TITLE: Well that's different, hmmmm

WRITING.TEXT: Got the ducati swingarm in the mail today and started fitting it. Now that I know it will work I'll order a wheel.

I've built several swingarms and frames from scratch for road and race bikes. This is fairly straight forward. The length is very close to stock. The biggest change will be the shock linkage which i wasnt happy with anyway.
Just like they mount stock.
I'm running a penske that I may end up re springing. I need to make an 11/16-18 to 1/2-20 threaded sleeve then it will bolt right up believe it or not.
1098 streetfighter

Update. Bike now supports itself. Machined a heim adaptor for the shock. It will need a stiffer spring but I have a few to choose from. I'll need a longer rear brake like and a 14t front sprocket for the gearing to be near stock. http://imgur.com/gallery/97oFZlT
Another update, swingarm modifications to work with the fz frame. http://imgur.com/gallery/07mciHY

WRITING.TITLE: Yep, I still hate cast aluminum

WRITING.TEXT: Lots of tracks require a guard for the brake lever if contact is made with another bike. If you bump someone with the clutch lever it's not going to cause you to go over the bars and possibly get you run over.
Ducati 1098
Not planning on it no.
Putting a ducati single sided swingarm on a yamaha fz09. Had to make room for the frame to clear during compression. More pics here. http://imgur.com/gallery/07mciHY http://imgur.com/gallery/97oFZlT
100% looks. The 1098 arm is heavier but the forged wheel is lighter. The single sided arm matches the frame beautifully. I'm building a ducati 900 superlight. Shooting for sub 300lbs wet.
Nice. I've got a green Nb in Chattanooga too.
Got a quote for an aluminum frame heat treat once, 2800$. That a no from me dog.
The biggest problem I had with this is some sort of wax or cutting fluid inside the cast section from machining. I couldn't get it all cleaned out but the quality of casting is excellent.
About 2'x4'
I was years ago under the name Truckinduc

I've never seen it before. The swingarm needed to be widened 4mm to fit the frame. I machined sleeves to adapt the pivot bolt. The obvious frame clearancing. I am using a Penske shock so there is a wide range of adjustments, but I did have to put a stiffer rate spring on it. I'll ride it for the first time today once i put a tire on the wheel.
I got out of building bikes for a while, been racing cars instead.
Funny thing is I bought this bike to leave alone and just ride while I finish my 4 other project bikes. That lasted 3 months.
Tire is too big but I'm riding it doing shock tuning. http://imgur.com/gallery/qe2a7NW.

WRITING.TITLE: Rear is done, now for a BST front. Opinions?

WRITING.TEXT: Yes. Rides great. I had to re spring the penske shock stiffer but that's it. Once I get the front wheel done I'll do some track days on it.
It's about 1000$ in parts but alot of modification to the swingarm is necessary. Far from a bolt on.
Here are a few pics of the adaptation process. http://imgur.com/gallery/07mciHY

I was hoping it wouldn't have such an interference and I could sell a kit for everyone to do it themselves. Unfortunately it doesnt look like yamaha consulted with ducati while designing the bike. I am happy with how well the frame and swingarm match. I'll take pictures from the other side this afternoon.
That's another build when I find a suitable wrecked bike to start from.
You never know someone's capabilities. I'll take more pictures today.

It's got about a half inch of clearance now but the tire moves away from the muffler under compression. I'm putting a smaller rear tire on it and changing the exhaust up soon but it works as is. I've already put 100 miles on this setup yesterday.

MOAR PICS for those who are interested. Current rear tire is a 190/55-17. I'll be replacing it with a 190/50-17. Also disregard the rusty chain, it's all I had laying around. I think the swingarm suits the bike well. http://imgur.com/gallery/4cLMw4d
Seat makes a world of difference. I've done 800 miles in 2 days on this one and wasnt uncomfortable.
Also, next on the to do list with some bigger sexier rotors. http://imgur.com/gallery/MSdAJvE

It is. I dont like the way it looks but it's very comfy. 800 miles in 2 days and my butt was happy. Unfortunately its heavy and the material developed a crack in it, plus the center section is coming loose. Pretty poor quality for an almost 500$ seat.
Not worth 130 bucks when I plan on building my own subframe and seat later.
It would probably be under warranty if I was the original owner but it came with the bike.

Does it rub what? Chain alignment was not changed from stock. I have the rear ride height lifted 1" currently. It rolls on the slider without my weight on it but it's fine with sag. I've put over 100 miles on it already with no issues.

The 1098 streetfighter swingarm is the only one long enough to work. Stock wheelbase. There was machining and welding involved. http://imgur.com/gallery/07mciHY
Eccentric adjuster and pinch bolts. The entire rear hub rotates to adjust the chain.
I'm the opposite. I can build about 14 bikes and 3 cars with the parts I have laying around.
Bronze

Swingarm needs to be widened 4mm at the pivot. Yamaha pivot bolt is smaller so you machine sleeves to adapt the pivot to the bigger ducati bearings. From the pivot bolt back everything is ducati. Some clearancing needs to happen for the swinger to compress over the odd shape of the yamaha frame, that's what I capped and welded. I had to adapt a heim to the penske shock and up the spring rate. I prefer the new motion ratio of the shock to the stock setup.
Also, I have a very trick xb9r you may like.

The load transferred into the frame is the exact same as the stock swingarm. The arm itself is under a complete different load but the transferred load is the same. Believe it or not there was no increase in unsprung weight with this setup, I just went out and weighed it all. Thats even with the wider ducati wheel and bigger tire. I also got rid of all the linkage which dropped a few pounds.
http://imgur.com/gallery/MSdAJvE
http://imgur.com/gallery/MSdAJvE
I'm not a fan of fake carbon. Hell I dont really even like the look of real carbon. I'll probably paint both the wheels bronze, I think that will go good with the rest of the bike.
Mostly looks. The wheel is lighter and I run a 190 tire now.

WRITING.TITLE: Not a machinist, but I still occasionally jump on a machine so I dont forget how.

WRITING.TEXT: Grew up around a manual shop, did CNC work for a few years in my teens, then went to programming. Now I do design and engineering along with inspection. Luckily I still get to use any of the machines I want. This was programmed at the machine. Luckily I didnt kill one because I need both of them.
Motorcycle rotor adaptors. Putting kawasaki rotors on a carbon honda wheel, for my yamaha.
It's got a ducati single sided swingarm and wheel. This is supposed to be my stock bike.
Yep stock length https://i.imgur.com/7bcHKnh.jpg https://i.imgur.com/RuDge22.jpg
Tell me I'm beautiful dammit
My 300$ daily
Fz09 triple
Fz09 triple
I wish I had 5 axis access.

7 CNC mills, 3 cnc lathes, 8 laser tables, 7 cnc press brakes, lots of welders. I make sheetmetal suspension parts mostly. Job shop, 100ish employees. I do laser scanning, reverse engineering, cmm inspection and design work. Most of my day to day work is designing products for customers.

Most important thing you need to do is learn how to use the machines BEFORE you become an engineer. That alone will make your life and the ones who work with you much easier. Most colleges have a machine shop or fsae team where you can learn tons. I guess I lucked into this job, there is no where else I could go in the city and do the same thing.
Solidworks, geomagic. Google faro laser scan.
I try to wave as flamboyantly as I can to the tough harley looking guys.
Scrubbing in a fresh front tire, I always put a knee down early with new tires ever since I had the front slide once.
Must have missed the point where I was scrubbing in a new tire, not trying to go fast.
I've noticed they wave to other cruisers but usually not at sportbike. .some cool people wave at everyone. Some people are dicks no matter what they ride.
No but when I loose the front tire I can use my knee to push and not low side.
Considering I've done it I'd say it does work.

WRITING.TITLE: 300$ 105k mile Lexus + 200$ lowering springs + wheels and tires I already had = one comfy daily.

WRITING.TEXT: Not worth a build thread. 2" drop springs, old honda k swap motor mounts on the struts for nice cushy bump stops, bent front knuckles for increased camber. 17x9.5 forget the offset rpf1 wheels, 245/45-17 tires. I've put 15k miles on it like this.
Plans to move the exhaust so you can actually get some decent lean on the right side? I love everything else about it.

WRITING.TITLE: Extruder clogging at certain z heights every time.
WRITING.TEXT: Hi everyone this is my first post here. I have a lulzbot taz 5 in an enclosure. The first 6 months were fine but now I cant get any prints to work. I run cura software. The current filament is polymaker pla. The extruder seems to clog about .250" above the table every time, despite different temp and speed settings. The first thing I did was clean the extruder and feed mechanisms. When that didnt work I swapped out complete heads but have the same problem. One thing I'm wondering is if the extruder feed is getting too hot and the filament is getting jammed, but the small extruder fan is running at 100% the entire time. Please help. I've attached a link to several photos showing past and present print quality. http://imgur.com/gallery/a3jCbs8
Thank you, ill go look for that. I honestly havent touched the printer in 6 months because I became so frustrated with it. I miss printing though so I need to figure it out.
It's a direct drive extruder and it seems fine.

My college dorm had an abandoned and blocked off top (4th) floor. The stairs were spiral stair cases and a fire hazard so the doors were welded shut. You could go into the bathroom, remove an access panel and climb up the pipes. It was spooky as hell up there but really cool at the same time. Automatic expulsion if caught. Totally worth it.
Started a test print right before I left work. I'll see what it looks like in the morning.
That's kind of what I'm thinking. I was hitting the heat sink with liquid co2 to cool it before and it seemed to help.
Last night's print was better but the same problem started to occur at about 1" from the bed. http://imgur.com/gallery/WgQUGv1

I have an everlast 200dv. First one killed itself about 6 months from when i got it. It took everlast about 2 weeks to actually admit something was wrong with it (wouldnt make an arc) before they sent a replacement. Friend bought the same machine and the high frequency has stopped working, he has to scratch start tig. My new (probably refurbished) machine is starting to act weird on AC. #8203; Another friend bought an AHP alphatig that broke 6 seconds in the first weld, no joke. #8203; My 1988 miller dialarc HF still runs good to this day.

Im assuming my new one was a refurb. #8203; AHP sent out a new main board which my friend swapped and it promptly fried too. He then said fuck it and sent the machine back. These things seem to be really hit or miss. #8203; I bought my everlast because a friend had one and it works well still to this day, but its not used very often.
Dont know, dont care.
That's my favorite when the tool changer decides to launch shit.

WRITING.TITLE: Track day fun, testing out the single sided swingarm.

WRITING.TEXT: http://imgur.com/gallery/9X2KDNA http://imgur.com/gallery/REiMxIu

Depends on a number of factors. The fz is lacking in many areas like the swingarm pivot is to narrow and the pivot bolt is is too small. The only real advantage to a single sided arm is wheel removal takes about 10 seconds and you dont have to touch the chain or rear brake. You also cannot mis align the chain.
Yah it drags on occasion even with the bike lifted more than stock. Sketchy.

Within 3 hours from my house I have Road Atlanta, Atlanta Motorsports park, Barber motorsports park, little Talledega, and National Corvette Museum track. All of the tracks host affordable track days and all tracks are excellent for cars. Little talledega is flat but the rest are complex and have huge elevation changes. Barber is the nicest track I've ever been to. I do time attack at road Atlanta in my civic and so far ive run a 1:36 with 200hp and a 1:32 with 300hp.

WRITING.TITLE: New to me 1125r, have a few questions.

WRITING.TEXT: Hey guys, just purchased this pretty rough 1125r. Bike was running badly so first thing I did was adjust the cable to the TPS and it helped a ton. Bike is a 2008. First question, what's the cold start idle? This revs at 3k-4k for a few minutes before finally settling down to around 1500rpm. Is this normal or do i have a problem like an air leak? Second question, what's the PIN number for in the gauge cluster? Previous owner knew nothing about it. My plans are to turn it into a race bike. I'll build a full race exhaust, front facing radiators, custom seat and subframe, rearsets etc. Thanks for the help.

WRITING.TITLE: Do tapered boring bars exist? Need to make this feature in 182 F11 steel. Help.

WRITING.TEXT: I was thinking a 5/8 or 3/4 shank solid carbide bar ground for clearance on the backside. Part has some pretty tight tolerances.
Smallish cnc. Part is 6"od, 12" long. Inside features are plus one thou, minus nothing. I think a .625 or .750 shank solid carbide bar with ground relief on the end is the only option.
I think I'll have to use a larger solid carbide bar with the back side ground down to match the taper.
the depth and small final diameter create a problem.
I just made that print with quick dimensions to ask this questions. Final tolerances havent been approved yet.
yep, quote was around 5k per part for 5 axis edm work.
nope, this is a fluid flow restriction device.

WRITING.TEXT: rear wishbones are thin wall aerofoil or oval shape chromoly (steel) tubing. #8203; rockers looked to be milled from aluminum, probably 7075. #8203; these are just guesses.

WRITING.TITLE: Play day

WRITING.TEXT: I recommend the movie "always" if you want good PBY action
Not a GP bike but cool anyways. Just a Ducati panigale.
old panigale vs new panigale "V4"

That and it moves the weight lower. Lower means less likely to wheelie, which means harder acceleration. #8203; Kyle Wieman (SP)? had to increase the stock fuel tank capacity of his panigale v4 to have enough fuel to make it the entire race distance in the motoamerica superbike series.

WRITING.TITLE: Borrowed my brothers samurai to play in the man made rock pile.

WRITING.TEXT: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m92MvtOHiPo](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m92MvtOHiPo) They moved a little but it was fun.
our laser department, 10 lasers and 2 hi def plasma, stays at about 110 degrees in the summer time. Its miserable.

WRITING.TITLE: Cheated on the samurai and got a Toyota. Planning on road tripping it from TN to Moab and back while camping in the bed. Wish me luck.

WRITING.TEXT: Pretty much, that and I have the room to camp in the back of the truck. The longer wheelbase helps a ton with hillclimbs. Also power steering.

WRITING.TITLE: Started building my first rig to drive from TN to Moab and back. Pictured here in big south fork TN.

WRITING.TEXT: 1984 straight axle toyota pickup. 5.71 diff gears, spool front and rear. I'm currently putting dual transfer cases in it and swapping the 33" tires for 37" to gear it taller on the highway. Also swapping the carb for fuel injection. I'm planning on building a shelf in the back to store plastic low profile containers underneath my mattress pad for food, clothes, gear etc.
yah, I live in nearby.
screenshot from a video. The only action photo i have unfortunately.
37s are to cruise at a respectable speed and rpm. I dont want to drive 1600 miles at 50 mph.

With the 33s there are 610 revolutions per mile, the 37s will have 544. At the same rpm I'd be doing 65 mph with the small tire, 73 mph with the large tire. Tacomaworld.com/tirecalc has a nice calculator.
Yes

I assumed so. It will still be geared relatively low even with 37s. I have lots of local mountains I can test it on. If all else fails I can tow it with my diesel but that takes all the adventure and fun out of the trip.
Besides the obvious terrible setup, holy shit that vice has seen better days.
90 on a downhill highway on 33" tires. very scary.

WRITING.TITLE: First rainy weekend trip, we had a blast in sequatchie TN
